title: 112_hr3484
content: The Act may be cited as the "Travel Regional Investment Partnership Act". The importance of travel and tourism is highlighted by Congress, with approximately 7,720,000 domestic jobs and 2.8% of the GDP dependent on this industry. In 2009, the industry suffered job losses and a decline in tourism output, emphasizing the need for public-private partnerships to promote growth. The Domestic Regional Tourism Grant Program is established under Section 3. The Secretary will establish a grant program through the Office of Travel and Tourism Industries to boost domestic regional tourism and create new markets. Grants will range from $100,000 to $1,000,000 and can be awarded to State tourism offices, local destination marketing organizations, and partnerships between government entities and tourism organizations. Priority may be given to regions with low tourism marketing contributions. The Secretary may prioritize regions with low tourism marketing contributions when awarding grants for promoting domestic regional tourism growth and creating new markets. Eligible entities must submit applications to the Secretary for grant consideration. Eligible entities must submit an application to the Secretary for a grant under this section, including a description of tourist promotion activities and a list of specific tourist entities partnered with by a State or local government. The government must provide details of tourist entities partnered with, the partnership agreement, how it will boost regional tourism, and the impact on job creation to receive non-federal funds for tourism promotion. The partnership must provide non-federal matching funds, either in cash or in-kind, equal to the grant amount received. In-kind donations are limited to 25 percent of the required matching funds. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress detailing the impact on job creation and employment within six months after grants are awarded. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress detailing travel-generated expenditures, tax receipts, and employment. Definitions include "local tourist entity" as a business engaged in tourism and "Secretary" as the Secretary of Commerce. $10,000,000 is authorized for the first 5 fiscal years for grants under this section. Authorization of $10,000,000 for grants under this section for the first 5 fiscal years after enactment.
